hints.content:
Let's interpret the frequency table.

Height | Number of Dogs
- | - 
$52\dfrac12\text{ cm}$| ${\mid}{\mid}{\mid}=3$ dogs
$53\dfrac12\text{ cm}$ | $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid}\mid\mid\mid = 8$ dogs
$54\text{ cm}$ | $\mid=1$ dog
$55\dfrac12\text{ cm}$ | $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid}=5$ dogs
$56\text{ cm}$| $\mid\mid\mid=3$ dogs
Each tick mark on the number line represents an interval of ${\dfrac{1}{2}\text { cm}}$.

There were $3$ dogs that measured a height of $\blueD{52\dfrac12\text { cm}}$.  

So, we place $3$ dots over $\blueD{8\dfrac12}$ on the number line.   

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled heights (centimeters) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 52, 53, 54, 55, 56, and 57. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 3 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 52 and 53. !

hints.content: Now, let's graph the other measurements on the frequency table.

The correctly graphed measurements are:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled heights (centimeters) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 52, 53, 54, 55, 56, and 57. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 3 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 52 and 53, 8 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 53 and 54, 1 dot above 54, 5 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 55 and 56, and 3 dots above 56. !

question.content:
Charlotte measured the height of all the dogs in her neighborhood to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{2} \text{ cm}$.

Height | Number of Dogs
- | - 
$52\dfrac12\text{ cm}$| ${\mid}{\mid}{\mid}$
$53\dfrac12\text{ cm}$ | $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid}\mid\mid\mid$
$54\text{ cm}$ | $\mid$
$55\dfrac12\text{ cm}$ | $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid}$
$56\text{ cm}$| $\mid\mid\mid$

**Graph the measurements from the frequency table on the following line plot.**    
*Click above the line plot to make dots for each of the measurements.*

[[☃ plotter 1]]
